stream_context.summary: Kaze brainstorms and refines the overworld for Return to Yoshi’s Island while explaining a major audio-engine rewrite and outlining a new batch of “single-mechanic” side levels that should push the hack to roughly 190–200 stars.

development_findings.summary: Kaze replaced Mario 64’s entire sound engine, reducing code size by ~5 KB, fixing bugs, freeing memory and achieving “huge performance improvements.”
development_findings.quote: I’m kind of just ripping it out, making my own. … I have reduced the code size by probably like five kilobytes and made a lot of bug fixes that make it a lot easier to make a game with the engine.

development_findings.summary: Overworld layout is now functionally complete except for one southern section; focus has shifted to adding landmarks and interactive buildings to prevent barren areas.
development_findings.quote: The world is done layout-wise, yes… Other than that, it’s all done layout-wise.

development_findings.summary: Bowser will drill through a magical barrier; the drill tunnel becomes its own level, and the barrier opens after collecting enough stars.

Kaze introduces a design rule of ‘single-mechanic levels’: short, low-scope stages that reuse existing code (manta-ray surf, mine-cart, cloud-cap, hide-and-seek, pinball roll, shell-dive race, gravity planet, etc.).
development_findings.quote: At this point I don’t want to add side levels that add that much work to the project. If anything I want the side levels that we now add to be based on a mechanic we already have.

development_findings.summary: Star count planning: post-brainstorm total sits at 189; goal is a clean 190 or 200, not an odd number like 192.
development_findings.quote: We have 189 stars planned now… If we get 11 more stars we have 200; I just don’t want to end up with like 192.

development_findings.summary: Hard world boundaries will be enforced by giant Bubbas that eat Mario; swimming fully around the island is intentionally disabled to avoid extra programming.
development_findings.quote: No… there’s going to be huge Bubbas that will eat you if you go out because I don’t want to deal with having to program that.

development_findings.summary: Engine and tool release intent: the hack’s engine optimisations will be open-sourced so other ROM-hackers can build on them.
development_findings.quote: Yes definitely, I do want people to use my engine to make more ROM hacks and to improve on my performance optimizations.

context_findings.summary: Kaze spent the last 4–5 straight days on the new sound engine and feels overloaded with tasks.
context_findings.quote: God, I had so much stuff to do today. … I’ve probably spent the last four or five days non-stop on it.

context_findings.summary: He relies on sponsor videos for income but is anxious about an agency (LFI) and Squarespace mishandling payments; the issue is resolved live on stream.
context_findings.quote: Something’s fucked up, and now I don’t know whether I’m actually going to get paid or not, which would be devastating.

context_findings.summary: Kaze is unconcerned about potential Nintendo takedowns and would rebrand the project if necessary.
context_findings.quote: If it happens, it happens. … I can still just turn it into my own branded game, hopefully.

context_findings.summary: Lives in Canada (originally from Germany), dislikes Reddit/4chan ‘time-sink’ culture, and intends to review a free Hong-Kong smartphone on his second channel for personal use.

biobak.summary: Actively suggests design tweaks (e.g., using plane layout vs timer for manta-ray level) and reminds Kaze of visual workload limits; Kaze notes project is ‘limited on Biobak time.’
biobak.quote: We’re limited on Biobak time though.

zeina.summary: Zeina is finishing the last area of ‘Forgotten Fortress’; star names are waiting on her completion.
zeina.quote: Forgotten Fortress doesn’t even have star names yet because we’re still waiting for Zeina to finish the last area.

key_stories.title: Sound Engine Overhaul
key_stories.summary: Frustrated with Mario 64’s dated audio, Kaze gutted the original engine and wrote a lean replacement, slashing size, fixing bugs, and boosting performance within a five-day sprint.
key_stories.challenge: Vanilla sound engine was inefficient and buggy.
key_stories.process: Ripped out legacy code, rewrote allocation logic, optimised routines.
key_stories.outcome: Engine is smaller, faster, more stable, and frees extra memory for the hack.
key_stories.key_quote: Once that’s done, we’re going to have a much stronger sound engine compared to the vanilla game.

key_stories.title: Sponsor Payment Scare
key_stories.summary: Kaze depends on sponsor deals organised by agency LFI but discovered invoicing and sales-tax errors that threatened his income; during the stream, the Squarespace payment issue is finally fixed.
key_stories.challenge: Uncertainty about being paid for recent sponsored videos.
key_stories.process: Communicated with agency; vented concerns live.
key_stories.outcome: Issue resolved mid-stream, though trust in agency is shaken.
key_stories.key_quote: Yo, my Squarespace issue just got resolved. Let’s fucking go.

key_stories.title: Filling the Empty Overworld
key_stories.summary: Kaze realises large stretches of Yoshi Island feel barren; he and chat brainstorm hospitals, playgrounds, treehouses, markets, and NPC migrations to breathe life into the hub.
key_stories.process: Listing potential buildings, events, NPC relocations (Poochie, oil-rig worker, arcade).
key_stories.outcome: Concrete list of structures and interactive spots to prototype next.
key_stories.key_quote: We need things we can put in here to make this feel more like a place where people live.
